Legal_Issue: Did the RPD commit a reviewable error in concluding that an IFA was available to the Applicants and was its finding on political persecution reasonable?
Credibility_Assessment: No credible link between extortion and political activities post-2012
Evidence_Type: Evidence showed police sought money, not political suppression
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged political persecution and extortion in Sri Lanka
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Extortion found to be criminally motivated, not politically motivated
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness, assessing justification, transparency, and intelligibility

Mitigating_Factors: Police actions deemed 'rogue' and for personal gain, not systemic
Risk_Assessment: No specific risk identified due to lack of political nexus
Threat_Source: Police officers acting for personal gain
Targeted_Victimization: Alleged targeting due to political activities, but not substantiated
Evidence_Type: Testimony, claims of political involvement post-2012
Evidence_Credibility: Not credible – no corroboration of political motive
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found claims lacked credibility regarding political persecution

Sub_Crime_Type: Police extortion, threats for financial gain
Mitigating_Factors: Actions seen as isolated criminal behavior, not state-sponsored
Criminality_Severity: High – abuse of power by officials
Risk_Assessment: Low – no objective basis for fear based on political opinion
Targeted_Victimization: Alleged due to political activities, but not proven
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence linking extortion to political opinion
Evidence_Type: Claims of political involvement, history of payments to police
Evidence_Credibility: Low – RPD found no credible link to politics
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicants' claims not credible or supported

Aggravating_Factors: Persecution based on religious affiliation (Shia) and writings
Mitigating_Factors: Availability of state protection in urban areas
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to religious and expressive activities
Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility finding by RPD
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - Refugee Convention grounds

Aggravating_Factors: Threats related to religious identity and public criticism of extremism
Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility finding

Aggravating_Factors: Incident part of broader pattern of persecution
Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high - part of coercive campaign
Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk due to property targeting as intimidation
Risk_Type: Property-related violence in context of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Undermined by conflicting testimony

Aggravating_Factors: Life-threatening violence due to religious expression
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found lack of credibility

Sub_Crime_Type: Property destruction with intent to intimidate
Aggravating_Factors: Use of fire as tool of intimidation and harm
Mitigating_Factors: Potential access to police protection in cities
Risk_Assessment: High - arson used as method of coercion
Credibility_Assessment: Negatively assessed by RPD

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting the applicant's refugee claim under sections 96 and 97 of IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Evidence_Assessment: Board assessed credibility of applicant's claims of detention and harassment; considered country conditions for Tamils in Sri Lanka
Decision_Outcome: Board rejected refugee claim; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish status as Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's credibility found lacking; no credible risk of persecution upon return
Legal_Rule: Sections 96 and 97 IRPA define eligibility for refugee status and protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on nationality (Tamil) and alleged history of detentions and harassment in Sri Lanka
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; no error found in Board's decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's testimony, country condition reports on Sri Lanka
Defendant_Response: Board maintained that conditions for Tamils in Sri Lanka have improved
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Board's rejection of refugee claim
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Board's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 (Convention refugee), s. 97 (person in need of protection)
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Assessment of refugee claim, credibility, internal flight alternative, generalized risk
Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies and lack of corroborative evidence
Evidence_Type: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of corroborative evidence
Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on Convention refugee status
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution risk as a Tamil in Sri Lanka
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, internal flight alternative, generalized risk
Application_Error: Alleged errors in law and fact assessment by RPD
Legal_Standard: Correct legal test for Convention refugee status
Application_Factor: Credibility, internal flight alternative, generalized risk

Legal_Issue: Application of legal test under sections 96 and 97 of the IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found not credible by the RPD
Evidence_Type: Lack of clear evidence of past persecution, lack of evidence of efforts to seek state protection
Legal_Provision: Section 96 (refugee definition - fear of persecution), Section 97 (risk of torture, cruel treatment)
Basis_of_Claim: Race, membership in a particular social group (Roma in Hungary)
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to RPD decision
Application_Factor: Country conditions indicating discrimination against Roma in Hungary
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to threats from individuals allegedly linked to police extortion in El Salvador
Misrepresentation_Element: Omissions in IMM 5611 form, inconsistencies between forms, police reports, and oral testimony
Procedural_Issue: RPD did not allow applicant to explain discrepancies in evidence
Evidence_Used: IMM 5611 form, police reports, oral testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Discrepancies in documentation and testimony not clarified
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on omissions and inconsistencies
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective and objective fear of persecution
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for credibility
Decision_Rationale: RPD violated procedural fairness by relying on discrepancies without giving applicant chance to respond

Aggravating_Factors: Targeted victimization based on gender or family status
Targeted_Individual: Primary applicant and minor family member
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient according to Board, but Court found sufficient basis for reassessment
Evidence_Credibility: Partially discredited by Board, but Court found misinterpretation of testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Contested – Board's assessment deemed unreasonable by Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board correctly analyzed the applicant's fear of persecution and linked it to a Convention ground
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of targeting of young Tamil males based on ethnicity
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Convention refugee definition under s. 96
Crimes.Application_Factor: Ethnicity, alleged political association, pattern of state-linked extortion

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Crimes.Legal_Framework: 1951 Refugee Convention, as incorporated by IRPA
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Young Tamil males in Sri Lanka

Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Insufficient due to involvement of government-linked groups
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious harm including detention, threats, and risk of torture

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Coercive extortion involving threats of denunciation
Crimes.Victim_Status: Tamil male refugee claimant from Sri Lanka
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated detentions, use of ethnic profiling, threat of false accusation
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: No indication of applicant’s criminal history
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – involved coercion, threats, and exploitation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk upon return due to unresolved targeting

Crimes.Risk_Nature: Threats of denunciation leading to potential detention or torture

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of repeated extortion incidents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible regarding experiences of extortion

Perpetrator_Type: Career soldier in El Salvador's army
Aggravating_Factors: Aware of atrocities but did not disengage
Planned operations linked to human rights abuses
Criminality_Severity: Serious reasons for considering complicity in international offenses
Evidence_Type: Testimony or record of military role and operational planning
Credibility_Assessment: Panel found actions constituted willing cooperation

National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to past complicity in war crimes
Risk_Factor: Continued service and acceptance of higher responsibilities in army
Nature_of_Acts: Participation in operations linked to war crimes
Admission_or_Involvement: Personal and knowing participation or toleration
Evidence_Credibility: Credible based on military record and role
Key_Evidence_Issue: Knowledge of crimes and failure to disassociate
Credibility_Assessment: Consistent findings by Immigration and Refugee Board and Federal Court
Credibility_Factors: Detailed account of role and awareness
Standard_of_Proof: Serious reasons for considering commission of war crimes
Governing_Provision: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Consequences_of_Action: Denial of refugee status in Canada

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to reject Mr. Bohorquez's refugee claim reasonable based on credibility findings?
Outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed, and the case is remitted for re-determination by a different panel.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board overlooked key evidence (threat to mother, land registry system misunderstanding, FARC's tracking ability), leading to unreasonable credibility findings.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Bohorquez claimed refugee status due to threats from FARC after refusing to inflate property values.
Application_Error: Overlooked key evidence in credibility assessment
Legal_Standard: The Board must reasonably assess evidence and consider all relevant facts when making credibility determinations.
Application_Factor: Unreasonable credibility findings due to ignored evidence
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision overturned; case remitted for re-evaluation by new panel

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision to deny the Applicant's work permit application reasonable based on the evidence provided?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application filed under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer misapprehended facts: ignored submitted work experience documents, overemphasized economic incentives without cost-of-living analysis, incorrectly assumed language barriers would prevent job performance
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to misapprehension of facts
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant provided relevant documentation and explanations
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Judicial review can be sought if decision is unreasonable or made without considering material evidence

Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Court found in favor of applicant
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside; case referred for re-evaluation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement to consider all material evidence

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Foreseeable risk of violence after verbal altercation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reliable based on officer documentation and procedural gaps

Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer erred in denying the TRV application and violated procedural fairness

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in dismissing the refugee claim based on irrelevant considerations and insufficient evidence

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with document submission requirements under Citizenship Act

Legal_Standard: Applicant must prove physical presence for 1,095 days

Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; case remitted for reconsideration by another judge

Violation_Type: Membership in organization likely to engage in violent acts

Procedures did not violate fundamental justice due to national security considerations

Crimes.Application_Factor: Appeal extension granted but did not invalidate prior deportation order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no question certified for appeal

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with residency obligations

Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Finality of determination after appeal period expires
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Determination becomes final upon expiry of appeal period; extension suspends but does not invalidate removal

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timeliness of appeal and extension granted by IAD
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Enforceability of deportation order during appeal

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not disputed; factual basis accepted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious Non-Political Crime under the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether serving a sentence for a serious non-political crime prior to entering Canada exempts an individual from Article 1F(b) exclusion
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review by the Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's U.S. conviction for drug offenses, sentence served (29 days in jail), and unserved probation period
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate they are not excluded under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant left the U.S. before completing probation, raising concerns about compliance with legal obligations
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes individuals who committed serious non-political crimes outside the country of refuge; assessed under Canadian standards of seriousness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Refugee status claim based on fear of persecution
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and severity of the offense under Canadian law, maximum penalty (life imprisonment), incomplete sentence
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, United Nations Refugee Convention
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed refugee status despite prior criminal conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record, sentencing documents, probation status

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection eligibility due to criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether the Board applied correct legal standard in assessing seriousness of crime
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Conviction records and sentencing details were available and considered
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Drug trafficking involving sale of cocaine and possession of marijuana
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Entered Canada after voluntary departure from the U.S.
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted in the U.S. for drug offenses carrying life sentence under Canadian law
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: No nexus between crime and political opinion or protected grounds
Crimes.Country_of_Origin: United States (offense committed prior to entry into Canada)
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division, affirmed by Federal Court
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Seriousness of drug offense under Canadian legal standards
Crimes.Legal_Framework: United Nations Refugee Convention, IRPA

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Eligibility for refugee protection following foreign drug conviction
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether conviction for selling $40 worth of cocaine and possessing 5 grams of marijuana constitutes a serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Federal Court judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of offense severity under Canadian law, despite minor value/quantity involved
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to rebut presumption of seriousness based on maximum penalty in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant departed U.S. involuntarily after conviction and before completing probation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Seriousness determined by potential penalty under Canadian law, not actual sentence served abroad
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Refugee claim based on fear of harm upon return to home country
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to Article 1F(b) exclusion
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of drug offense, equivalence under Canadian Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, unserved probation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Refugee Convention, Canadian criminal law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Sought refugee protection despite criminal history
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Foreign conviction records, sentencing information, probation status

Application_Facts: Alexandr Pikulin claimed asylum due to alleged persecution in Israel; the Refugee Protection Division rejected his claim
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to analyze credibility and subjective fear of persecution; inadequate assessment of state protection and nature of persecution

Credibility_Assessment: Inadequate credibility assessment by the tribunal
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for reconsideration by a different panel

Legal_Standard_Applied: Justified, transparent, intelligible decision within acceptable range based on facts and law
Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked sufficient reasoning on credibility, subjective fear, state protection, and persecution
